come off.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The label had come off, so there was no way of knowing what was on the disk.
come off.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Dyson came off his bike as he rounded the last corner, but wasn’t badly hurt.
come off.translation[0].definitions[2].d: if something that has been planned comes off, it happens
come off.translation[0].definitions[2].e: In the end the trip never came off.
come off.translation[0].definitions[3].e: It was a good idea, but it didn’t quite come off.
The performance on the first night came off pretty well.
come off.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to stop taking a drug that you have been taking regularly
come off.translation[0].definitions[4].e: It wasn’t until I tried to come off the pills that I realized I was addicted.
come off.translation[0].definitions[5].d: to be the most or least successful, or get the most or least advantages from a situation
come off.translation[0].definitions[5].e: As far as pensions go, it’s still women who come off worst.
come off.translation[0].definitions[6].d: used to tell someone that you do not believe what they are saying
come off.translation[0].definitions[6].e: Oh come off it! You can’t seriously be saying you knew nothing about this.
